TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in the town of PERSON , GPE .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , for DATE she had been living as part of a family with her stepfather , mother and CARDINAL - brother and wanted to associate herself more closely with them by taking the surname of her stepfather and also a patronymic derived from his forename .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a request with ORG in PERSON ( hereinafter “ the Registration Office ” ) seeking to change her patronymic from ORG to ORG ) .

CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE ORG refused the applicant ’s request , referring to LAW in GPE , approved by ORG , which provided that the patronymic of a physical person could only be changed in the event of a change of forename by his or her father .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant challenged this refusal in the ORG . She complained that her patronymic , along with her forename and family name , was part of her full name and she had the right to change it . She maintained that the refusal violated her constitutional rights , was unconstitutional and was not based on law . She further contended that she had good reasons for changing her patronymic - to disassociate herself from her biological father and associate herself more closely with her stepfather and CARDINAL - brother .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant changed her original surname from PERSON to the surname of her stepfather , PERSON , which was also the surname of her mother and CARDINAL - brother .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG found that ORG had acted in accordance with the law , in compliance with LAW , and so dismissed the applicant ’s complaint . It found that a change of patronymic was only legally possible when the father of the person concerned had previously changed his forename . Therefore , given that the applicant ’s father had not changed his forename , the applicant ’s request for change of her patronymic had not been in compliance with the law . The court also noted that ORG provided more detailed regulation of the relevant provisions of the LAW , LAW and LAW and did not conflict with them .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the decision of the first - instance court , holding that its conclusions were based on law .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed an appeal lodged by the applicant on points of law . It held , in particular , that the argument put forward by the applicant that the new LAW limited the right to change a patronymic was based on an incorrect interpretation of the provisions of LAW .
CARDINAL . The relevant provision of the LAW reads as follows :
“ ... The content and scope of existing rights and freedoms shall not be diminished as a result of the enactment of new laws or in the amendment of laws that are in force . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the LAW read as follows :
“ Registration of a change of surname , forename or patronymic of a citizen of GPE shall be conducted by civil status registration offices at his or her place of residence .

Registration of a change of surname , forename or patronymic shall be notified to those civil status registration offices in GPE which keep the records of births , marriages and divorces of those who have changed their surname , forename , or patronymic . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the Code read as follows :
“ CARDINAL . An individual acquires rights and responsibilities and exercises them under his or her own name .

The name of an individual who is a citizen of GPE consists of his or her surname , forename and patronymic , unless the law or custom of the national minority to which they belong provides otherwise ... ”
“ CARDINAL . An individual has the right to a name ... ”
“ CARDINAL . An individual who has reached DATE has the right to change his or her surname and forename in accordance with the procedure prescribed by law .
CARDINAL . An individual ’s patronymic can be changed if his or her father changes his forename ... ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the LAW read as follows :

CARDINAL . Where family relations are not regulated by this LAW or by agreement ( contract ) between the parties , the rules of this LAW governing similar relations shall apply to them ( analogy of statute ) .
CARDINAL . Where the analogy of statute can not apply to the regulation of family relations , these are governed by the general principles of family law ( analogy of law ) .
CARDINAL . The patronymic of a child shall be determined by the forename of her or his father .

CARDINAL . NORP The patronymic of a child who was born to an unmarried woman , where the paternity of the child is not recognised , shall be determined by the forename of the person who the child ’s mother called his or her father .
“ CARDINAL . If a father changes his name , the patronymic of his child who has reached DATE shall be changed with the latter ’s consent . ”

CARDINAL . In her commentary on LAW ( Ромовська З. В. Сімейний кодекс GPE : ORG коментар. – DATE вид. , ORG і доп. – К. : Видавничій Дім Ін Юре , DATE . GPE CARDINAL , CARDINAL ) , Professor Z. V. ORG , a drafter of the LAW , noted , in particular , in respect of Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL :
“ CARDINAL . ... The forename of the person recorded as the child ’s father automatically defines the patronymic of the child ...

CARDINAL . Every child , must , in all circumstances , have a " patronymic " even when the identity of his or her real father is not established . In that case , the " patronymic " can be invented . ”

“ CARDINAL . A child who has attained the age of CARDINAL , already has his or her place in society , is preparing for independent life and associates his or her name with the patronymic which appears in his or her documents . Therefore , his or her consent or objection to the change of patronymic will be crucial . A situation may thus arise in which the father has changed his forename , while the patronymic in the documents of his son or daughter remains [ the old one ] .

CARDINAL . Can the patronymic be changed when the forename of the father has not been changed ? There is no response to this question in LAW . However , LAW ] allows the analogy of statute and law and can help in finding a solution in such a situation . ”
CARDINAL . The Decree provided inter alia :
“ CARDINAL . Citizens of GPE are allowed to change their surname , forename and patronymic when they attain DATE .
CARDINAL . NORP ... A refusal to change a surname , forename or patronymic can be challenged before the court in accordance with the established procedure . ”

CARDINAL . As with LAW , the procedure approved by this ORG provided that any citizen who had reached DATE could apply for a change of surname , forename and patronymic and that a refusal of such a change could be appealed against to the courts . The procedure further provided that :
“ CARDINAL . change of surname , forename or patronymic shall not be allowed if
a ) the applicant is under investigation or trial or has been convicted ;
b ) there are objections from the police . ”

CARDINAL . This ORG replaced the ORG ’s Resolution of DATE . It set forth a procedure for changing all parts of the individual ’s name ( surname , forename , patronymic ) . CARDINAL provision refers exclusively to patronymics :
“ CARDINAL . ... The application of an individual for a repeated change of patronymic shall be lodged and examined in accordance with this procedure . ”
CARDINAL . The procedure further provides for the circumstances in which an application for change of name can be refused :
“ CARDINAL . The grounds for refusal to allow the change of name are :
( i ) the applicant is under investigation , trial or administrative supervision ;
( ii ) the applicant has a criminal record which has not been cancelled or overturned in accordance with the procedure established by law ;
( iii ) there is an official request from the law - enforcement agencies of foreign countries for the applicant ’s placement on a list of wanted persons ;
( iv ) the applicant submits false information .
Refusal to allow the change of name can be appealed against to the court . ”
